pull.title: refactor: use `_MiB`/`_GiB` consistently for byte conversions
pull.body:
### Problem
Byte-size conversions in the codebase currently show up in many equivalent formats (multiplication/division chains, shifts, hex/binary literals), which creates a maintenance burden and makes review error-prone - especially considering the architectural differences of `size_t`.
Inspired by https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34305#discussion_r2734720002, it seemed appropriate to unify `Mebibyte` usage across the codebase and add `Gibibyte` support with 32/64 bit `size_t` validation.

### Fix
This PR refactors those call sites to use `""_MiB` (existing) and `""_GiB` (new), and adds the encountered value/pattern replacements to unit tests to make review straightforward, and to ensure the conversions remain valid.
The literals are overflow-checked when converting to `size_t`, and unit tests cover the 32-bit boundary cases.

Concretely, it replaces patterns such as:
* `1024*1024`, `1<<20`, `0x100000`, `1048576`, `/ 1024 / 1024`, `* (1.0 / 1024 / 1024)` â†’ `1_MiB` or `double(1_MiB)`
* `1024*1024*1024`, `1<<30`, `0x40000000`, `1024_MiB`, `>> 30` â†’ `1_GiB`

### Note
In the few places where arithmetic involves signed values, the result is identical to the previous code assuming those quantities never become negative.

commit of the target branch.

* A sanitizer issue, which can only be found by compiling with the sanitizer and running the

* An intermittent issue.

Leave a comment here, if you need help tracking down a confusing failure.

verification.payload:
tree 6c301b1dbd299be714eaab44b89244cb4f03130b
parent f7e0c3d3d370a4e5b4060fefcb9e8d83e2533bbc
author LÅ‘rinc <pap.lorinc@gmail.com> 1769607884 +0100
committer LÅ‘rinc <pap.lorinc@gmail.com> 1769723252 +0100

util: add _GiB for Gibibyte conversions

Introduce `operator""_GiB`, sharing the overflow-checked conversion logic with the existing `operator""_MiB`.

Use `1_GiB` in a few existing places where it is a drop-in replacement (e.g. `1024_MiB`, `1<<30`) and extend unit tests to cover boundary behavior.

events.message:
util: add _GiB for Gibibyte conversions

Introduce `operator""_GiB`, sharing the overflow-checked conversion logic with the existing `operator""_MiB`.

Use `1_GiB` in a few existing places where it is a drop-in replacement (e.g. `1024_MiB`, `1<<30`) and extend unit tests to cover boundary behavior.

verification.payload:
tree 1b52abd2d9abe1bc1ddbe76d21283b7f5fb8b73e
parent 0e6f1e340f70334463082ca57e25ec48e1986ec5
author LÅ‘rinc <pap.lorinc@gmail.com> 1769607504 +0100
committer LÅ‘rinc <pap.lorinc@gmail.com> 1769723284 +0100

refactor: use _MiB consistently for Mebibyte conversions

Replace hard-coded MiB byte conversions (e.g. `1024*1024`, `1<<20`, `1048576`) with the existing `_MiB` literal to improve readability and avoid repeating constants.

In the few spots where arithmetic involves signed values, the result is identical to the previous code assuming those quantities never turn negative.

Extend unit tests to cover the 32-bit `size_t` overflow boundary and to assert equivalence for integer and floating-point conversions.

events.body:
ACK 792d679a54dcaf359628554fa2681c03d05f1676

Concpt. review: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34435#pullrequestreview-3724982952

Checked trickier hex literals actually match _MiB/_GiB-versions.

Diffed against previously reviewed push and aside from commit re-ordering, only saw minimal deduplication in gib_string_literal_test.

comments.body:
Should use `string_view` or `const char*` to avoid heap allocations for the happy path.
```suggestion
constexpr size_t ByteUnitsToBytes(unsigned long long units, std::string_view exception_msg)
```

(Edit: I realize this is only run in a constexpr context so it's probably negligible in practice, but would still be nice to fix).

I wonder if multiplying with `size_t` instead of unspecified integer expression risks flipping negative function inputs into positive output values, but it's probably only used with positive inputs regardless.

nit: I suspect clang-format prefers:
```suggestion
template <unsigned SHIFT>
```

```
$ git grep "template <" src/ | wc -l
807
$ git grep "template<" src/ | wc -l
424
```

Thanks, will do it on next push

Edit: pushed this nit + rebased
Yes, so why not use `const char*` to avoid the "heap" allocation (usually in constexpr/consteval) in cases where the function succeeds and the exception isn't even thrown?

That would be true without `constexpr`, as shown in https://godbolt.org/z/TGb57r7zz.
But with `constexpr` it has zero runtime impact since the exception string is completely optimized away  e.g. `8_MiB` and friends are always compile-time constants, see https://godbolt.org/z/7rhfqc39f.
But it would eliminate a string import, so I don't mind, pushed.
In 112b9914639aab450f0aadc187f6985f56cb7e70: How about putting the GiB commit first and only touch this line once instead of twice?

Good idea, haven't thought of that! Pushed - also simplified the [`gib_string_literal_test`](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/compare/e5b573f18ac2e13508330ada6e92c8155f86a0e5..792d679a54dcaf359628554fa2681c03d05f1676) to remove some duplication.

remark:
* Initial thought: "`(2^32) >> 30` should be `2^2 == 4`, not `3`".
* Then I realized `uint32_t`-max is `(2^32)-1` and rounds down.
